children.subject:
Great post and I hope more people continue this discussion! 

 

The bigger, more important question is what do you want out of your career and life? Hamming is talking to people who want to advance any field as far as they can and get as much low hanging fruit as possible. Nothing wrong with this (“contributing to the sum total of human knowledge” sounds slick), but you should be certain that you want that exactly and not some adjacent goal. See also Denero’s final CS61A lecture. 

 

The 7 year rule is decent advice if it aligns with your goals. Unlike most advice, it’s an easy heuristic to remember and apply: if I’ve been thinking about the same problem for 7 years, pivot to a subfield I don’t have much experience/reputation in, which might have insights or metaphors that might get me unstuck in some other field. It’s still just a heuristic, though, and focused planning is a better idea. I’d recommend spending a few days thinking through (a)-(h) of this post to make a plan. Then test your plan and revise: if a time traveller told you that you failed to achieve your goal, which part of the plan would you guess failed? Fix it and repeat. Then go test your plan. We really aren’t automatically strategic, and dispassionately thinking about and testing plans seems like it would go a long way. 

 

I recommend Francis Crick’s autobiography, What Mad Pursuit. It’s a lot less serious than Hamming’s talk, but Crick also hopped between disciplines a few times in his life. Biology is famously unintuitive (evolution doesn’t care about the simplest or most elegant solution!), and Crick’s explanations of how the field developed different hypotheses and experiments is a great primer in how to approach research.

history.content: Just chiming in here to say that I think this thesis would be a fantastic basis for a panel discussion with some people who have taken different approaches to their careers. If there is interest, I would be happy to arrange a panel like this. I can already think of a few people who would be excellent participants.

children.subject: I am certainly interested in Heather's panel idea! Click "helpful" if you are interested too.

history.content: @OP One book suggestion is Range by David Epstein. His philosophy has some similarities to Hamming's.

Whenever I think of roadmapping my life any time more than a year down the line, I reflexively jump back to the great computer scientist Richard Hamming's essay "You and Your Research." Towards the end, in a question and answer session (page 14 at YouAndYourResearch.pdf (virginia.edu)), Hamming gave a poignant but controversial piece of advice:

Question: You mentioned the problem of the Nobel Prize and the subsequent notoriety of what was done to
some of the careers. Isn't that kind of a much more broad problem of fame? What can one do?
Hamming: 2
 Some things you could do are the following. Somewhere around every seven years make a
significant, if not complete, shift in your field. Thus, I shifted from numerical analysis, to hardware, to
software, and so on, periodically, because you tend to use up your ideas. When you go to a new field, you
have to start over as a baby. You are no longer the big mukity muk and you can start back there and you
can start planting those acorns which will become the giant oaks. Shannon, I believe, ruined himself. In fact
when he left Bell Labs, I said, ``That's the end of Shannon's scientific career.'' I received a lot of flak from 

my friends who said that Shannon was just as smart as ever. I said, ``Yes, he'll be just as smart, but that's
the end of his scientific career,'' and I truly believe it was.  
You have to change. You get tired after a while; you use up your originality in one field. You need to get
something nearby. I'm not saying that you shift from music to theoretical physics to English literature; I
mean within your field you should shift areas so that you don't go stale. You couldn't get away with forcing
a change every seven years, but if you could, I would require a condition for doing research, being that you  
will 4
 change your field of research every seven years with a reasonable definition of what it means, or at the
end of 10 years, management has the right to compel you to change. I would insist on a change because I'm
serious. What happens to the old fellows is that they get a technique going; they keep on using it. They
were marching in that direction which was right then, but the world changes. There's the new direction; but 

the old fellows are still marching in their former direction.  
You need to get into a new field to get new viewpoints, and 5
before 6
 you use up all the old ones. You can do
something about this, but it takes effort and energy. It takes courage to say, ``Yes, I will give up my great
reputation.'' For example, when error correcting codes were well launched, having these theories, I said,
``Hamming, you are going to quit reading papers in the field; you are going to ignore it completely; you are
going to try and do something else other than coast on that.'' I deliberately refused to go on in that field. I
wouldn't even read papers to try to force myself to have a chance to do something else. I managed myself, 

which is what I'm preaching in this whole talk. Knowing many of my own faults, I manage myself. I have a 

lot of faults, so I've got a lot of problems, i.e. a lot of possibilities of management.

To me, his logic is sound, but a bit non-mainstream. I fear, for example, one may be too irrigorous with just seven years' experience in a subfield, even though earlier in the essay Hamming talked about the exponential importance of compounded hard work.

My question is, to what extent are his words good career planning advice?

How can one best adapt his words to make a career plan of one's own? 

P.S. I like a diversity of minds. What are some other great articles on long-term career/research planning?

My question is, to what extent is this good career planning advice?

history.subject: To what extent is Richard Hamming's seven-year prescription good advice?
